channel.title: Perl Weekly newsletter
channel.description: A free, once a week e-mail round-up of hand-picked news and articles about Perl.

item.title: London Perl and Raku Workshop
item.description: October 26, 2024, in London, UK

item.title: Toronto Perl Mongers monthly meeting
item.description: July 25, 2024, Virtual event

item.title: Monatliches Raku-Monger Treffen
item.description: July 18, 2024, Im Roten Ochsen

item.title: Continuous Integration (CI): GitHub Actions for Perl Projects
item.description: July 14, 2024, in Zoom

item.title: Purdue Perl Mongers
item.description: July 10, 2024, Virtual event

item.title: Boston.pm monthly meeting
item.description: July 9, 2024, Virtual event

item.title: The Perl and Raku conference
item.description: June 24-28, 2024, in Las Vegas, NV, USA

item.title: NICEPERL's lists
item.description:
Great CPAN modules released last week;
StackOverflow Perl report.

item.title: Speaking Goat Latin on the fastest bus to town
item.description: Do you like GitHub Copilot? This post would make you fall in love. Kudos for your effort.

item.title: Goat on the Bus
item.description: Raku is the choosen language for the blog post. With line-by-line discussion, the algorithm becomes easy to follow. Keep it up great work.

item.title: The Weekly Challenge #274
item.description: Nice breakdown of task is so handy to follow the logic. Keep it up great work and thanks for sharing.

item.title: Latin buses
item.description: Another Perl regex magic approach, TMTOWTDI. I am a big fan of DIY tool as always. Thanks for sharing the knowledge.

item.title: Bus Route, Bus Goat, Under My Umbrellamaaaaaaaaaaaa
item.description: If you are looking for something fresh, this is the post for you. It is not limited to just Perl and Raku but also Python and Elixir. You really don't want to skip it.

item.title: These busses got class-maa!
item.description: Perl one-liner with all the magics for you. Once decoded, it appears so simple. Smart approach, I must admit.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge 274
item.description: Goat Latin is an ideal task for our in-house master of Perl one-liner. The end result is worth checking out. Well done.

item.title: not understood
item.description: Raku regex in action all the way to get the end result. Discussion is good enough to decode the workings. Great work.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge 274: Goat Latin
item.description: A very simplistic approach yet very powerfull. Raku did score more than Perl in this case with the use of subset. Highly recommended.

item.title: On the Goat Route
item.description: Pure regex solution, a very daring attempt. Kudos for the effort, thanks for sharing the knowledge.

item.title: Waiting at the Bus Stop
item.description: Line by line discussion of Bus Route task is worth checking out. Impressive work, well done.

item.title: Goat Bus
item.description: Keeping it simple and easy to follow algorithm. Just use of regex and substr enough to get the job done. Keep it up great work.

item.title: Concerning Goats and Buses
item.description: Loved the story telling format of the post. Above akk the content is quite engaging too. Keep sharing.

item.title: RECAP - The Weekly Challenge - 274
item.description: Enjoy a quick recap of last week's contributions by Team PWC dealing with the "Goat Latin" and "Bus Route" tasks in Perl and Raku. You will find plenty of solutions to keep you busy.

item.title: The Weekly Challenge - 275
item.description: Welcome to a new week with a couple of fun tasks "Broken Keys" and "Replace Digits". If you are new to the weekly challenge then why not join us and have fun every week. For more information, please read the FAQ.

item.title: Bowing to the inevitable
item.description: Have you read the book, Data Munging with Perl? Dave is asking the readers what they would to see in the second edition of the book.

item.title: Dr. StrangeYAML or How I Learned to Stop Worrying and Love the LLM
item.description: Do you work with LLM? If yes then you should give YAMLScript a go.

item.title: How I Spent My Perl Toolchain Summit v2024
item.description: The wait was worth it, finally we have the report by Olaf.

item.title: Continuous Integration (CI): GitHub Actions for Perl Projects (Free Virtual Workshop on July 13)
item.description: In this virtual event you will learn why and how to use GitHub Actions as a CI system for your Perl projects. The meeting is free of charge thanks to my supporters via Patreon and GitHub. Besides this event I am running many more, so make sure you check the Code Mavens meetup group and also register to it.

item.title: #674 - What's new in Perl v5.40?
item.description:
Hi there,

Around two weeks ago, 9th June 2024, the much awaited Perl v5.40 was released. As always, the production release was packed with cool core enhancements. Thanks to the entire team of volunteers who worked day in day out to get the latest release smoothly. I would like to share my Top #5 core enhancements as below:

  • New __CLASS__ keyword
  • :reader attribute for field variables
  • New ^^ logical xor operator
  • try/catch feature no longer experimental
  • for iterating over multiple values at a time is no longer experimental

Today is the Day 1 of The Perl and Raku Conference 2024 in Las Vegas. The entire day is dedicated for Hackathon. The main attraction of Day 2 is going to be the keynote talk by Curtis Poe and Damian Conway. Who is your favourite speakers at the event? I am looking forward to the talk by work colleague, Julien Fiegehenn. There is another speaker I am looking forward to, Ingy döt Net, who is scheduled to talk about YAMLScript and Clojure. There is another talk, Build a better README, is one of my favourites by Jason Crome. A recent post, Dr. StrangeYAML or How I Learned to Stop Worrying and Love the LLM by Ingy is not to be missed. If you like playing with LLM then this is your friend.

Enjoy rest of the newsletter.
item.dc:subject: editorial
